report_title: Online Office and School Supplies Sales Industry Report
executive_summary: The Online Office and School Supplies Sales industry has experienced strong revenue growth, increasing at an estimated CAGR of 4.6% to $2.7 billion over the past five years, including an expected increase of 4.4% in 2023 alone. Positive macroeconomic factors and consumer trends have boosted industry revenue during most of the period. Rising income levels between during the five-year period coupled with an increasing percentage of services conducted online, led to strong growth for industry operators.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Unlike many other industries, the Online Office and Schools Supply Sales industry fared well throughout the coronavirus. Because of social distancing and shelter-in-place orders across the United States, nonessential businesses were forced to shut down. However, online operators did not have to contend with such an issue. In fact, e-commerce sales skyrocketed in 2020 alone as consumers and businesses exclusively shopped online.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Large Array of Industry Products Strengthens Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The wide range of products and price points offered by the industry attracts a large pool of customers and businesses, which typically leads to a steady stream of revenue for industry operators. Certain items, such as school supplies, are viewed as less discretionary than other industry products.

Technological advancements and increasing accessibility have also greatly benefited industry operators. As the number of broadband connections have steadily increased, more individuals have had access to online retailers. Additionally, because of the growth in smartphones, many operators have developed mobile apps that enable customers to seamlessly purchase products on-the-go from their devices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving Macroeconomic Conditions Will Drive Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Continued improvements in macroeconomic conditions over the next five years will benefit the Online Office and School Supply Sales industry. With strengthening economic conditions, including household income level increases, the industry can expect a boost in sales as consumers have more disposable income to spend.

Industry consolidation will persist over the next five years, as companies look to expand their market share and optimize efficiencies through mergers and acquisitions. With continued consolidation, larger online retailers will gain more market share, potentially influencing pricing and product trends in the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Operators Will Focus On Customer Satisfaction
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Operators in the Online Office and School Supply Sales industry will prioritize improving customer satisfaction in their strategy over the next few years to remain competitive. These strategies include efforts to enhance websites and apps, reduce delivery times, expand their product offerings, and offering superior customer service.

industry_definition: This industry sells school and office supplies or a combination of school and office supplies with stationery, notebooks, writing instruments and other related products.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level - high - steady

key_trends: Rising disposable income and corporate profit have spurred an increase in spending on industry products
The top players compete on the basis of price, quality, product offering and customer service
Economic uncertainty and rising unemployment have contributed to declining consumer confidence
Rising consumer spending will likely result in increased industry demand
Industry operators will likely seek to expand their network and establish new warehouses
Existing operators will likely focus on increasing their marketing expenditure
High barriers to entry have limited the number of successful enterprises within the industry

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes individuals that purchase office supplies for an at-home business and large corporations.
This segment includes consumers who are purchasing industry products for personal use.
This segment includes consumers who are purchasing industry products for personal use.
This segment includes consumers who are purchasing industry products for personal use.
This segment includes consumers who are purchasing industry products for personal use.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment includes a broad range of office supplies, such as document wallets, diaries, address books, binders, folders, paper trays, pen trays, office stamps, pens and pencils and break room supplies.
This segment includes ink and loose paper and is the second-largest product segment.

The school supplies segment includes folders, notebooks, mathematical tools, index cards, pens, pencils and highlighters. Demand varies by age group, with high school-aged students and post-secondary students needing different items than younger students.

tier_1_suppliers: Office Stationery Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Office Stationery Manufacturing in the US
Art & Office Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industry has benefited from an increasing number of consumers shopping online, which has ultimately risen because more consumers have switched to broadband. The internet enables customers to shop around for the best price, and the ease with which the internet can be used for research enables consumers to shop among competing online stores.

Operators should ensure that their product range is as extensive, if not more extensive, as those found in traditional stores. Online retailers of office and school supplies have the advantage of stocking a more significant volume of merchandise over their brick-and-mortar counterparts, given that they are not constrained by shelf space.

business_locations.location_description: The West is the largest region by industry establishment. Within the region, California is the largest state by establishment, technology hubs such as San Francisco draw numerous online retailers to the state. Higher than average disposable incomes of California residents further fuel spending on industry products. A large population coupled with proximity to major trading hubs on the Pacific coast allure various operators.

The Southeast region ranks as the second-largest region in terms of industry establishments. The region is the most populated region in the United States, making it a strategic place for operators to locate as there is a large nearby customer base. Additionally, the Southeast is home to several large trading ports which gives operators who locate in the region easy access to trade activity.

The Mid-Atlantic is the third-largest region by industry establishment. The region has a robust and established transportation network, including airports, water transit systems, and highways, which makes it a strategic location for online retailers since they send their products nationwide. The accessibility of critical transportation networks promotes efficient delivery and distribution capabilities, attracting operators to the region.
The large population of the Southwest attracts operators.

regulations_points.regulation_title: STREAMLINED SALES AND USE TAX AGREEMENT
regulations_points.regulation_description: This regulation is critical to the Online Office and School Supply Sales industry as it simplifies sales tax collection across multiple states for retailers, reducing costs and administrative burdens.
Key regulations like the Sherman Act, the Wilson Act, the Clayton Act, and the Robinson-Patman Act form the backbone of antitrust actions.
This act, along with various state laws, administrates matters like minimum wage, overtime and working conditions.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is low and steady.
Competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Industry operators primarily compete based on price, product range and brand awareness.
Large operators tend to offer a broader range of products because consumers often prefer to shop at stores that provide a variety of office and school supplies.
The four largest players benefit from brand awareness, enabling them to offer competitive prices while still maintaining a profit.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is dominated by a few large players.
The sizable presence of established companies makes it challenging for new players to gain a foothold in the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the Largest Expense for Operators
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 62.5% of industry revenue in 2023. Purchases, or costs of goods sold, consist of office and school supplies that are purchased from vendors for resale to consumers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Online Office and School Supply Sales industry has a low to moderate level of capital intensity, with most investment requirements being in the form of warehouse space, computer equipment, hosting services, bandwidth and packing equipment.

Industry operators outlay capital on technology to establish, implement and maintain their websites, on which consumers place orders. Establishing and maintaining databases requires computers, printers, software programs for electronic payment systems, firewalls and more.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE INDUSTRY IS PARTIALLY PROTECTED FROM ECONOMIC SHIFTS
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Online Office and School Supply Sales industry has experienced moderate volatility in revenue over the past five years, influenced by changes in disposable income and supply chain disruptions.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE E-COMMERCE BOOM HAS INCREASED VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The rapid expansion of e-commerce has increased volatility in the Online Office and School Supply Sales industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Online Office and School Supply Sales industry has disrupted traditional brick-and-mortar businesses. However, broader technological changes across the retail sector also affect industry operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Online retailers in this industry sell a variety of different types of office and school supplies at a wide range of price points.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on wealthy consumers or households?
FAQs.answer: Sales are heavily dependent on consumers and businesses as each market generates a significant portion of revenue. However, due to the low price point of products, operators are not reliant on wealthy consumers and households.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Rising input costs are not substantial enough to greatly affect industry sales. Rising input costs are typically gradual and relate to the paper and plastic used to manufacture notebooks, writing instruments and other related products.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Larger and well-known operators benefit from working directly with office and school supply manufacturers to reduce purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Due to the nature of the industry, operators have benefited from the rise of online sales over the past few years. Additionally, operators benefit from consumers becoming more comfortable with purchasing industry products online.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Operators have introduced new technology, like electronic data interchange (EDI), which enable the exchange of information between stores within the industry and between operators further up the supply chain.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Many states have enacted e-commerce tax laws in recent years, which puts these retailers on a more level playing field with brick and mortar stores. Recently, the Supreme Court has ruled states are legally allowed to collect tax from online sales.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with trade organizations, such as the National Retail Federation, to stay up to date on changing regulations and consumer trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit has been pressured because of internal competition among the top four operators, leading to intense price-based competition within the industry.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
How do you manage your stock? Have you had issues in the past with not having enough stock on hand?
FAQs.answer: Operators need to be able to control stock on hand to ensure that they have an adequate number of popular items.

FAQs.question: Are you able to quickly adjust to new technology? What new technology have you recently implemented?
FAQs.answer: Ever-changing software systems, internet speeds and personal information security systems require operators to continually update their business to keep pace with recent technology.

FAQs.question: How do you keep customers? What tactics do you use to attract more customers?
FAQs.answer: It is important to have a loyal customer base to attract repeat buyers and ensure continued sales.

FAQs.question: In which industries do your clients primarily participate? How do you monitor and respond to trends in these industries?
FAQs.answer: Businesses are the primary buyers of industry products. As their profit grows, they are more likely to spend on office supplies.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of changes in per capita disposable income? How do you stimulate demand when disposable income levels are low?
FAQs.answer: Consumers represent a major market for industry products. As disposable income increases, consumers are more likely to spend money on additional office supplies for home use or school supplies.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in the percentage of business conducted online? How has the move to online purchases of home furnishing affected your business?
FAQs.answer: Businesses and consumers have increasingly chosen to use the internet to purchase goods in lieu of visiting brick-and-mortar stores. As this trend continues, industry operators will likely benefit as demand shifts from their brick-and-mortar counterparts.
